raw_response:
Beshisha, the Tunisian Jewish Djerban dish, appears as a dense, slightly sticky paste or mixture when served. Its consistency is neither soupy nor stew-like but rather firm enough to hold shape while still soft and pliable. It is visually a rich, dark brown to deep golden color due to the roasted grains and spices. When served, Beshisha is typically shaped into energy balls or formed into a paste, rather than served as a liquid or chunky stew.
